newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: Court finds Britain did enact product liability directive.
newsitem.headline: Court finds Britain did enact product liability directive.

text.p: The European Court of Justice dismissed on Thursday a claim by the European Commission that Britain had failed to properly implement the Community's product liability directive.
The court said the Commission did not make its case that Britain did not correctly implement defences to manufacturers' liability.
The directive calls for "a fair apportionment of the risk betwen the injured person and the producer" to allow a producer to prove fault could not have been foreseen.
The Commission argued Britain broadened the defence for manufacturers by converting strict liability into negligence.

The court said that even if the British legislation adopted different wording than the directive, the British law kept the burden of proof on the manufacturer, and rejected a subjective standard as to what is known rather than what should have been known by the manufacturer.
Additionally, the court noted the scope of national laws must be assessed in the context of member state court interpretation, and the Commission failed to do so.
"Failure of a member state to fulfil obligations - Article 7 of Directive 85/374/EEC - Incorrect Implementation"
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

application for a declaration that, by failing to take all the measures necessary to implement Council directive 85/374/EEC of 25 July 1985 on the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the member states concerning liability for defective products (OJ 1985 L 210, p. 29), in particular article 7(e) thereof, the United Kingdom has failed to fulfil its obligations under that directive and under the EC treaty
